New York City is called the Capital of World.  It is a city of neighborhoods and communities, of art, fashion, and culture, of skyscrapers, bridges, and parks; it a center for international diplomacy, for global finance, for commerce and technology.  This course offers a range of topics that enable students to critically engage in a distinct New York experience through a variety of lenses as they navigate the complexities of NYU.  Each section asks students to explore a theme through readings, a field trip, and reflective writing statement.  We will investigate how New York City corresponds to larger U.S. cultural norms, and what factors make New York City a distinct place, physically and culturally.  The sections are taught by NYU’s Faculty Fellows in Residence.  After completing the faculty-led component of the course, student will be asked to continue to engage with NYU programs and New York City-based activities throughout the semester to encourage integration to the site.
